Authors:
tom viaene, Charles F. Delwiche, Stefan A. Rensing, Jiri
Friml
Title:
Origin and evolution of PIN auxin transporters in the green
lineage
Abstract:
Polarized auxin transport is crucial for many
developmental processes in flowering plants and requires the PIN-FORMED
(PIN) family of auxin efflux carriers. However, the impact of polar
auxin transport and PIN proteins on the development of non-seed plant
species and green algal lineages is largely unknown. The key in
comparative biology in order to understand the origin of fundamental
plant processes is the comparison with the appropriate related
organisms, which in many cases will be streptophyte algae, the closest
living relatives of land plants. Using recently available sequence
information from these and other non-seed plant species, we have
constructed a preliminary phylogenetic framework and present several
hypotheses for PIN protein evolution. We postulate that PIN proteins
originated in streptophyte algae, but note that their function in these
organisms remains unknown. We further propose that the initial
subcellular localization of PIN proteins was presumably at the
endoplasmic reticulum and that plasma membrane localization was acquired
during land plant evolution. We also suggest that the PIN proteins are
evolutionarily distinct from another family of auxin transporters at the
ER, the PIN-LIKES (PILS) proteins.
